There are several legal issues that can arise with distressed properties, including:

1. Liens: Distressed properties may have liens placed on them, which are legal claims against the property for unpaid debts. Investors can mitigate this risk by performing a title search and obtaining title insurance.

2. Code Violations: Distressed properties may have code violations that must be addressed before the property can be sold or occupied. Investors should conduct a thorough inspection of the property to identify any code violations and seek legal advice to ensure compliance with local regulations.

3. Tenants' Rights: If the distressed property has tenants, there may be legal issues involving their rights and obligations. Investors may need to navigate eviction proceedings or negotiate new lease agreements with existing tenants.

4. Environmental Hazards: Distressed properties may have environmental hazards, such as asbestos or lead, that must be remediated before the property can be sold or occupied. Investors should conduct an environmental assessment to identify any hazards and seek legal advice to ensure compliance with federal and state regulations.

To mitigate these risks, investors should work with experienced real estate attorneys who can perform due diligence to identify potential legal issues and provide guidance on how to resolve them. It's also crucial for investors to obtain appropriate insurance coverage, such as title insurance, liability insurance, and environmental insurance, to protect against potential legal claims.
